The fact is that "Ethnic-specific" health studies estimate that "240,000-325,000 African Americans are HIV positive." Even more shocking is the overrepresentation of African American women in the count of HIV positive women in this country. Statistically, even though they only make up about 12-13% of the overall female population in the U.S., 67.4% of all known HIV infected women and 57% of women diagnosed with "full blown" AIDS in this country are African American women. Although there has been a decline in AIDS cases in other groups, the rate of HIV infection among African American women continues to increase. AIDS is the most cited reason for death among African American women between ages 25 and 44 (CDC).

Whether people think talking about the connection between race and AIDS is insensitive or not, you have to look at it to understand the full reality of the epidemic. You have to know the enemy to fight it effectively. It is clearly the case that the risk of contracting the virus is not equally distributed. Contrary to politically correct pronouncements, AIDS is not an "equal opportunity" disease as suggested earlier in the thread. The people who are at highest risk are those who have frequent unsafe types of sex as well as for those who are IV drug users. 
 
 The demographic groups with the highest rates of AIDS are homosexuals and blacks. They are contracting the disease at high rates because of high rates of unsafe sex and IV drug use. Rates are high for homosexuals because of high rates of unprotected anal sex. The rate is high for blacks because of high rates of IV drug use and unsafe heterosexual sex (e.g. sex without condoms, less monogamous sex, sex with IV drug users and partners with other sexually transmitted diseases that produce open sores). There is also research suggesting that compared to other groups, blacks may be tend to be more vulnerable to the disease for genetic reasons.
 
 Of course other demographic groups have many individuals living with the disease, but the difference in rates is still very striking. If we hide these facts because we want to be nice, we will fail to focus resources on high risk groups, and they will be the ones to suffer from your niceness.

If we only had your statement to base policy on, we would end up wasting a great deal of resources because there is no targeting. In the end, helping people with this disease is ten times more important than concerns over the consequences of telling people sensitive facts. I find today's ultra-sensitive environment very counterproductive.
